parameters.source_text:
Case 12-6
Posttraumatic Stress Disorder:
Funding Therapy for a Preexisting Condition
James Schultz, a soldier who had served in Iraq, had been involved in a
combat operation in which three of his comrades were killed by an IED
(improvised explosive device). He had been on that same road just prior to
the explosion. He deeply grieved their deaths; subsequently, he spoke with
an Army psychologist about his “survivor guilt.”
He returned to the United States and to his previous job. Ironically,
within six months he was involved in a car accident in which the other driver
was killed. Then he developed frequent flashbacks to his war losses,
affecting his ability to concentrate. While under therapy with a psychiatrist,
Lucille Bell, he heard from a friend that Eye Movement Desensitization and
Reprocessing (EMDR) treatment had been used successfully in such cases.
However, when he sought treatment from Dr. Bell, he learned that his insur-
ance company considered his problem as a “preexisting condition” and
denied coverage.

data.vignette: You are the insurer’s medical director reviewing an appeal. A veteran with long-standing combat-related trauma has worsening flashbacks and can’t work after a recent fatal car crash. His psychiatrist recommends EMDR, which is available in-network, but the plan excludes treatment for conditions judged “preexisting.” The clinician argues the current decline is tied to new events and that delaying care risks further deterioration. Approving would require an exception using funds reserved for other denied claims and could set a precedent; denying follows the policy but leaves him with limited options.
data.choice_1: Grant a one-time exception to cover EMDR now, despite the preexisting-condition exclusion.
data.choice_2: Deny coverage and adhere to the policy, directing him to standard covered services or self-pay options.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove clinical ambiguity about whether this is truly “preexisting” or not, and fix benefit/urgency qualitatively. For example: replace “clinician argues the current decline is tied to new events” with “he meets criteria for acute exacerbation after the crash; EMDR is a standard, likely effective treatment for this flare.” Replace “risks further deterioration” with “delay is likely to prolong severe symptoms and impaired function.” Avoid implying the decision hinges on causation disputes rather than the coverage ethics.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: State a clear decision deadline tied to care needs, e.g., “You must decide today to authorize the next week’s sessions,” or “A decision is required within 48 hours for treatment to start.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim extraneous framing and sharpen the minimum decision-relevant facts. For example, drop nonessential descriptors (“veteran,” “combat-related”) unless needed for coverage context, and specify the concrete alternative covered option (e.g., “short-term supportive therapy only”) so the ethical tradeoff is clear without extra narrative.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the insurance constraint medically/legally plausible. Specify the setting as a plan type that can exclude preexisting conditions (e.g., “a limited-benefit supplemental policy” or “a non-U.S. private plan”), or reframe as an internal utilization-management policy excluding a specific therapy for previously diagnosed PTSD rather than a blanket ‘preexisting-condition’ exclusion.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Remove the arguable factual/coverage classification dispute and make the tension explicitly about whether to make an exception despite clear policy. E.g., change to: “He has chronic PTSD that worsened after the crash; the plan’s contract excludes PTSD treatment as preexisting, but the appeal process allows discretionary exceptions.” Keep both options as: (A) exception to meet urgent need vs (B) apply policy to preserve fairness/resources.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify that both parties agree on the clinical facts (chronic PTSD, recent worsening) and that the disagreement is not whether it is ‘really’ preexisting, but whether it is ethically acceptable to override the exclusion. Remove “clinician argues the current decline is tied to new events” and replace with a shared acknowledgment plus a discretionary exception clause.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the pull of each option so neither is the obvious ‘right’ answer. Add one sentence making denial clinically and ethically defensible (e.g., “He can access covered trauma-focused therapy and meds, though it may take weeks and may be less targeted”), and make approval ethically costly in a concrete way (e.g., “approving would consume most of the plan’s limited exception fund this quarter, likely forcing stricter denials for similarly severe appeals”). Avoid implying EMDR is uniquely necessary or that denial guarantees deterioration.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove sympathy-leaning identifiers and prognostic language that nudges approval. Example edits: change “A veteran with long-standing combat-related trauma” to “A middle-aged patient with chronic PTSD”; change “recent fatal car crash” to “recent motor vehicle collision involving a death” or simply “recent motor vehicle collision”; replace “delaying care risks further deterioration” with a neutral statement such as “the clinician reports symptoms have worsened since the collision”; replace “leaves him with limited options” with “would require the patient to use covered alternatives or pay out of pocket.”

data.vignette: You are the medical director for a limited-benefit supplemental health plan. A middle-aged patient has documented chronic PTSD, with marked worsening after a recent motor vehicle collision. His psychiatrist requests a short course of EMDR to start next week; EMDR is a standard treatment for acute symptom flares. The contract excludes PTSD treatment that was diagnosed before enrollment, but the plan allows rare discretionary exceptions funded from a small quarterly pool. If denied, he can use covered supportive therapy and medications, though access may take weeks and may be less targeted. You must decide within 48 hours.
data.choice_1: Approve an exception to cover the requested EMDR course despite the exclusion.
data.choice_2: Deny the exception and apply the contract exclusion, directing him to covered alternatives or self-pay.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize comparative clinical claims that make one option look medically better (e.g., “standard treatment,” “less targeted”). Replace with fixed qualitative statements about benefit/limits for each option without implying clear superiority. Example: change to “EMDR is one accepted treatment for trauma-related symptom exacerbations; supportive therapy/medications are also accepted but may not match his preference.” Avoid “may take weeks” unless matched by similar delays for EMDR, or state both are available on similar timelines.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim extraneous details and clarify only decision-relevant facts. Remove “motor vehicle collision” if not essential; or keep only “recent trauma.” Clarify the size/scarcity of the discretionary pool in one phrase (e.g., “a small fixed quarterly exceptions budget”). Specify whether approving this could reduce coverage for other members later (without adding new characters/patients). Remove timeline details about access unless essential and balanced.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Strengthen defensibility of BOTH options by balancing the moral/clinical costs. Currently denial appears clinically inferior due to delay/‘less targeted.’ Make alternatives timely and clinically reasonable (e.g., “covered trauma-focused therapy is available within days but not EMDR”), and make approval carry real tradeoff (e.g., “approving uses a meaningful portion of the limited exceptions budget, potentially forcing stricter denials later this quarter”). Keep this framed as policy/coverage ethics rather than ‘best treatment’.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is pre-loaded as medically or morally superior. Edit the vignette to remove/soften steering language like “EMDR is a standard treatment” and “alternatives… may be less targeted,” and instead note that covered supportive therapy/medications are also reasonable treatments but may not match the psychiatrist’s preference. Add one sentence making the cost of approving concrete (e.g., approving would likely consume most of the quarterly exception pool, risking denial of other members’ urgent requests, and could set a precedent). If keeping time pressure, balance it by stating symptoms are severe but not imminently life-threatening.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove wording that subtly favors approval by portraying EMDR as clearly superior. For example, change “EMDR is a standard treatment for acute symptom flares” to “EMDR is one evidence-based option for symptom exacerbations.” Change “less targeted” to a neutral phrase such as “a different modality.” Avoid implying delay only for covered care; clarify comparable timing for EMDR if uncertain (e.g., “EMDR could start next week if authorized”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and remove potentially distracting administrative details while preserving the ethical tension. For example, replace “limited-benefit supplemental health plan…small quarterly pool” with “a limited plan with a small discretionary exceptions fund.” Clarify the clinical timeline: specify whether PTSD predates enrollment and that the collision triggered an exacerbation. Consider deleting “documented” and “marked” unless clinically necessary. Ensure the decision point is the exception request vs strict contract enforcement, without additional side issues.

data.vignette: You are the medical director for a limited health plan with a small discretionary exceptions fund. A member with longstanding PTSD has had a severe symptom worsening after a recent traumatic event. Their psychiatrist requests coverage for EMDR with an out-of-network therapist; EMDR could begin soon if authorized. The plan covers other trauma-focused psychotherapy and medication management on a similar timeline, but not EMDR. Approving would consume most of the remaining exceptions fund for this quarter and may shape how future requests are handled. What should you do?
data.choice_1: Approve a one-time exception to cover EMDR with the requested therapist.
data.choice_2: Deny the exception and authorize covered trauma-focused therapy and medications within plan benefits.

Their psychiatrist requests coverage for EMDR with an out-of-network therapist; EMDR could begin soon if authorized. The plan covers other trauma-focused psychotherapy and medication management on a similar timeline, but not EMDR. Approving would consume most of the remaining exceptions fund for this quarter and may shape how future requests are handled. What should you do?

choice_1.choice: Approve a one-time exception to cover EMDR with the requested therapist.

choice_2.choice: Deny the exception and authorize covered trauma-focused therapy and medications within plan benefits.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the ethical value conflict explicit by (1) stating the member strongly prefers EMDR and has tried/failed or cannot tolerate covered trauma-focused options, (2) briefly noting EMDR is evidence-based for PTSD and the clinical urgency/risks of delay, and (3) describing the justice/stewardship impact: approving would likely force denial of other members’ imminent exceptions requests and set a precedent for out-of-network coverage.

data.vignette:
You are the behavioral health medical director for a regional health plan. A 34-year-old member, Maya R., has chronic post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) after multiple assaults. She has daily intrusive memories and nightmares, hypervigilance, panic in public settings, and has missed work repeatedly. Over the past month she has presented twice to the emergency department for severe panic and passive suicidal ideation, and her therapist documents escalating self-harm urges when trauma is discussed. 

Maya strongly prefers eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR) and is requesting an out-of-network exception because there is no in-network EMDR provider within 60 miles who can see her within the next 10–12 weeks. She has already completed a full trial of SSRI pharmacotherapy and has tried two covered, in-network trauma-focused therapies (prolonged exposure and cognitive processing therapy). She stopped both due to worsening dissociation and inability to tolerate the sessions despite appropriate pacing and safety planning; her clinicians document these as failed/intolerable trials rather than nonadherence. Her psychiatrist notes EMDR is an evidence-based, guideline-supported treatment for PTSD and believes delaying effective trauma-focused care increases risk of decompensation, ED visits, and possible hospitalization.

The requested out-of-network EMDR course is 12 sessions at $250/session. Your plan has a limited exception budget this quarter due to multiple high-cost requests (e.g., urgent out-of-network oncology and pediatric specialty care). Approving this exception would likely require denying other members’ imminent exception requests and could set a precedent leading to more out-of-network psychotherapy approvals that the plan cannot sustainably fund.

choice_1.choice: Approve an out-of-network exception for EMDR now (12 sessions) with care coordination and safety monitoring, given the documented failed/intolerable trials of covered trauma-focused options, the lack of timely in-network access, and the clinical risk of delay.

choice_2.choice: Deny out-of-network EMDR coverage at this time and require use of covered in-network options (e.g., telehealth trauma-focused therapy with an in-network clinician, interim skills-based therapy, medication optimization), while placing the member on an expedited waitlist and offering a single-case agreement only if access remains unavailable after a defined timeframe.
